newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico peso firmer at close on dollar inflow.
newsitem.headline: Mexico peso firmer at close on dollar inflow.

text.p: The Mexican peso enhanced mid-session strength at the close of trade on Thursday on capital flow into local financial markets prompted by lower rates payable on U.S. long bonds, dealers said.
"Foreign dealers bought dollars this morning but then sold them heavily when (U.S.) long bonds and Wall Street recovered," a trader said.
The benchmark 48-hour peso and its 24-hour stablemate ended 1.8 and 2.4 centavos firmer, respectively, at 7.9060/7.9110 and 7.8960/7.9010 per dollar.
Same-day peso contracts had earlier closed 0.7 centavo firmer at 7.9075/7.9120 per dollar.
The U.S. 30-year Treasury bond was up 19/32 to yield 6.92 percent at the same time Mexican foreign exchange markets were closing.
The Mexican bourse blue chip IPC index .MXX was meanwhile up 43.03 points at 3,817.04.
Other traders said the peso recovered on the favorable outlook for April inflation figures due out shortly after the close of trade.
A Reuters survey of Mexico City financial houses MEX22 showed they forecast an average 1.11 percent increase in the consumer price index for April, down from 1.24 percent in March.
